Events.Sub-event: Contrast in German Front and Southeastern Orientation of XV Corps
Events.Sub-event_summary: In post-COBRA period, German left flank disorganization contrasts with firmness elsewhere; Allies seize southeastern orientation of XV Corps to exploit collapse.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_41: In the midst of the fast-moving post-COBRA period, the utter disorganization of forces on the German left flank contrasted sharply with unexpected firmness in other parts of the German line. To exploit the collapse on the German left and to deal with continuing tenacity elsewhere, the Allied command seized upon the southeastern orientation of the XV Corps.

Weather.Weather_text: Warm summer weather with occasional rain and fog in early August 1944

Events.Sub-event: Bradley's Direction for XIX Corps Advance
Events.Sub-event_summary: Bradley directs XIX Corps to advance through Tessy, Vire, Domfront to Mayenne; thinks XV Corps might advance to upper Sélune River, pinch out VII Corps at Mortain, meet XIX at Mayenne.

Sub-event_fulltext.Paragraph_42: In the post-COBRA exploitation during the last days of July, when General Bradley had directed XIX Corps to advance along an axis projected through Tessy, Vire, and Domfront to Mayenne, Bradley thought the XV Corps might advance toward the upper reaches of the Sélune River, pinch out the VII Corps at Mortain, and meet the XIX Corps at Mayenne.<sup>[31](https://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USA/USA-E-Breakout/fn22.html#fn31)</sup> Unfortunately, XIX Corps had not gotten much beyond Tessy by 3 August. In contrast, XV Corps had met no "cohesive enemy front" in moving to the St. Hilaire-au-Harcouët-Fougères-Rennes line, and the 79th Division reported no enemy contact at all at Fougères.<sup>[32](https://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USA/USA-E-Breakout/fn22.html#fn32)</sup> To exploit this contrasting situation was tempting.
